data.text:
“A work consisting of editorial revisions, annotations, elaborations, or other modifications which, as a whole, represent an original work of authorship” (17 U.S.C. § 101) is called a derivative work he original copyright owner typically has exclusive rights to “prepare derivative works based upon the copyrighted work” (17 U.S.C. § 106(2)). Learn more in this copyright article here.

Are derivative works infringing a copyright work?

It is considered copyright infringement to make or sell derivative works without permission from the original owner, which is where licenses typically come into play. If permission is granted by license or assignment, then creation of the derivative work is not considered copyright infringement.

Can I Register a copyright in a derivative works?

The right to register a copyright in a derivative work requires no permission or license. However, when registering the derivative work copyright, you must disclaim the portions previously copyrighted.

What is a transformative work?

It is often said that there are no completely original works, and that everything includes some prior works. When a new work is unique enough, it is said to be transformative. It is fair use to utilize a previously copyrighted work into a transformative work.

Copyright law is complicated. Copyright infringement has serious consequences. There are rarely ‘black and white’ answers under copyright law. If you have any questions, make sure you touch base with a copyright lawyer with the expertise to do a risk assessment.

Copyright Lawyer Enrico Schaefer

If you are considering copyright issues, a copyright attorney with the right experience can help you determine your rights and identify risks.
